race.name: UNBOUND Gravel XL
race.tagline: 350 miles of Kansas limestone hell with zero aid stations. The ultimate test of whether you actually like riding bikes or just think you do.

logistics.explanation: Kansas City or Wichita airports are 1.5-2 hours away. Emporia hotels book fast and spike during race week. As one rider notes: "Unbound Gravel temporarily increases the population of Emporia, Kansas by 50%." Small-town infrastructure gets overwhelmed by 12,000 visitors.

length.explanation: 350+ miles puts you through the night and into the next day. Rob Britton chased Lachlan Morton "for like 200 kilometers" through darkness to win in 17:49:51. Serena Bishop Gordon captures the distance: "Time was an illusion. We rode for nine hours in the dark, and it went by so fast — full focus the whole time."

technicality.explanation: Sharp Flint Hills limestone slices tires while you make constant line choices in darkness. The 2023 mud turned bikes immovable - Chris Mehlman went "eight miles in two-and-a-half hours" through Kansas clay that "resembles concrete" and clogs drivetrains in seconds.

elevation.explanation: 14,000 feet of climbing across relentless prairie rollers that accumulate over 350 miles. No massive climbs, but the constant elevation changes through Council Grove, Lake Kahola, and Pillsbury Crossing grind down legs over the ultra-distance.

climate.explanation: Late May Kansas delivers 24+ hours of weather variability including 60 mph winds. Heather Jackson experienced "an hour of chaos" when her headlamp failed in darkness. Anne-Marije Rook found sunrise brought "heat and humidity" after looking forward to the "boost of energy that light usually provides."

altitude.explanation: Emporia sits at roughly 1,200 feet elevation. No altitude challenges here - just pure suffering at modest elevation through the rolling Flint Hills prairie.

adventure.explanation: Night riding through Flint Hills prairie creates otherworldly experiences. Anne-Marije Rook encountered "two cows headed straight toward me" at 4 AM after 13 hours in the saddle. Rob Britton found the adventure transformative: "The sunset was incredible, the sunrise was amazing. Riding through the night was amazing."

prestige.explanation: The most prestigious ultra-distance gravel race in the world. The XL predates the ultra-gravel movement and set the template everyone else copies. Winning here puts your name in gravel history.

race_quality.explanation: Life Time provides GPS tracking via Trackleaders and clear self-supported rules. The format means less official support but professional execution. Lachlan Morton lost his headlight but found it "exactly what I was looking for" - a pure test of self-sufficiency.

experience.explanation: Ultra-endurance suffering that rewires perspective. Chris Mehlman was "one button away from quitting for the eight hours of darkness" but convinced himself finishing "would be the proudest result I had achieved." Anne-Marije Rook hallucinated utilities poles becoming humans while sleep-deprived at mile 300+.

community.explanation: The XL attracts ultra-endurance believers seeking the original Unbound spirit. Small lottery-limited fields create tight bonds among riders who understand the commitment. As Heather Jackson notes, "It's more of an adventure. It's a little less cutthroat than the 200."

field_depth.explanation: Elite cyclists Rob Britton, Lachlan Morton, Heather Jackson, and Anne-Marije Rook compete alongside seasoned ultra-endurance specialists like Jay Petervary and Sean Mailen. Course records keep falling - Britton shattered the previous mark by over 2 hours in their epic duel through Texaco Hill.

value.explanation: At $250 entry for 350+ miles with GPS tracking included, the per-mile value is exceptional. Joe Meiser captures the reward: "Everyone who finishes is a winner. Finishing means that you started something that only a small fraction of riders will ever consider doing."

expenses.explanation: Moderate total cost with $250 entry, but hotels hit $140-200/night during race week. Add flights to Kansas City or Wichita, plus essential gear like reliable lighting and GPS trackers for self-supported racing. Budget $800-1200 total for the weekend.

black_pill.headline: 36 Hours of Reckoning
black_pill.content: Let's be absolutely clear: the XL is not a longer version of the 200. It's a completely different beast that happens to share a start line. Zero aid stations. Zero crew support. Just you, 350 miles of tire-shredding limestone, and whatever you can carry or buy at gas stations in the middle of nowhere Kansas. You'll ride through the night without sleep, make decisions while hallucinating from exhaustion, and discover exactly what kind of person you are when everything hurts and nobody is coming to save you. Less than half of first-time starters finish. The course record is under 18 hours - most mortals need 25-35. If you're not prepared to suffer alone in the dark, questioning every life choice that led you here, this race will break you. That's the point.
warnings: Completely self-supported - no aid stations, no crew allowed
DNF rate is significant - many don't finish
Requires GPS tracker and navigation skills
Sleep deprivation is real - 17-36 hour effort
Kansas weather is unpredictable and unforgiving

final_verdict.one_liner: The longest gravel race that matters, where the Flint Hills strip away everything but what's left of your soul.
final_verdict.should_you_race: You need to finish a 200-miler first, preferably two. The 36-hour cutoff sounds generous until you're grinding limestone in your 16th hour with 150 miles still ahead. Self-supported means what it says—no crew, no checkpoints, just you and whatever gas stations stay open past midnight in rural Kansas.
final_verdict.alternatives: Gravel Locos 400k gives you similar distance with more technical terrain and aid stations if you want slightly less suffering. Mid South's 100-miler lets you test yourself against the same sharp gravel and weather without the full commitment to psychosis.

course_description.character: Unbound XL is a 350-mile commitment to Kansas limestone gravel that slices tires and punishes poor line choices across the rolling Flint Hills. The course feels like prairie purgatory — constant undulations that never let you settle into a rhythm, with long stretches between gas station salvation points. Sharp, chunky gravel demands constant vigilance while the relentless rollers chip away at your soul one hill at a time.

suffering_zones.label: First Reality Check
suffering_zones.desc: Eskridge arrives right when the course diverges from the 200-mile route, marking your entry into true isolation. The limestone has already announced its intentions on your tires and legs.

suffering_zones.label: The Northern Wasteland
suffering_zones.desc: Alma to Alta Vista represents the most remote section — 75 miles of Kansas nothingness with no resupply options. Your planning mistakes become apparent here, usually around 2 AM.

suffering_zones.label: The Gravel Gauntlet
suffering_zones.desc: Past Council Grove, fatigue meets the course's most technical terrain. Every rock wants to end your race while your body starts the serious negotiations about quitting.

suffering_zones.label: The Final Crucible
suffering_zones.desc: The last 30 miles back to Emporia feel longer than the previous 100. Your bike is destroyed, your body is broken, but the finish line finally becomes real.

course_description.signature_challenge: The 75-mile gap between meaningful resupply points turns nutrition into a high-stakes chess match. Most riders crack not from the hills or the gravel, but from running out of food or water in the Kansas void where gas stations close at 10 PM and your mistakes compound in the darkness.

videos.title: My First ULTRA Bike Race (Unbound XL - 350mi / 563km)
videos.description:
Unbound XL is a gravel bike race over 350 miles, 563 kilometers, in the farm lands of Emporia Kansas. This bike race is fully self supported event, meaning EVERYTHING you eat, wear, or repair is all on you. 

98% of the course is gravel roads, you ride through the night, meaning you need lights. There are 6 gas stations along the route where you can get food and water.

I learned A TON from this experience, and will change a lot of my personal set up for next year. Below is my set up in detail and what I would change. 

My setup was a SURVIVAL approach vs RACE, which I feel now was a bad idea. I was so confident I could win or podium, that I didn’t want bad mechanical luck take me out. 

So I leaned on my fitness to over come weight, but it was just too heavy and I could have streamlined the setup much more. But I just didn’t know what to expect. 

BODY: 
Hydro pack w/storage 
- chain
- Tire
- Jacket
- tubes
- tools
- flow hydration (calorie mix)
- ketones 
- 3L of water w/ketones 
- head lamp
Cargo bibs for xtra storage 
MTB shoes & pedals 

BIKE
Frame bag (all batteries for lights, GoPros, and battery bank)
Top tube bag (2 GoPros)
Saddle bag (C02 + levers)
Aero bars 
Front fork (30mm) 
42 IRC doublecross tires 
Cadex 35 AR wheels 

FANNY PACK
2,000 calories

0:00 Intro
1:01 Act 1- Setting the scene
5:14 Act 2- Everything goes wrong
14:36 Act 3- Just like that, things got better
23:18 Act 4- All is fair in love & bike racing
31:50 Act 5- I love this shit
41:55 Ending talk

videos.title: Charlotte man wins, breaks record on 350-mile cycling race
videos.description:
A Charlotte man is back in the Queen City after winning the 350-mile Unbound Gravel bike race with a record-breaking time of 20:17:19. 

"The course is slightly different every year but it always starts and ends in Emporia, Kansas," said William Harrison. "And previously the record was somewhere around 22 or 23 hours so I took a couple of hours off that time."

Jane Monreal learns more from him: https://www.wcnc.com/article/news/local/william-harrison-charlotte-nc-cyclist-sports-local/275-e9bfb45e-2452-4036-aedb-32737cad7507

videos.title: Unbound Gravel XL Launch - Friday in Emporia!
videos.description:
Unbound Gravel XL Launch - Friday in Emporia!
Neil Taylor and Matt Fowler from Gravel Guru spent Friday hanging out in downtown Emporia before Unbound Gravel.

They caught the excitement and watched the start of the Unbound XL.

Check it out to see what the vibe was like before race day!
#thisisgravel #GravelGuru #UnboundGravel #EmporiaKS #UnboundXL #GravelCycling
videos.transcript:
Neil, here we are. It is Friday of
Unbound Week in downtown Emporia. Dude,
it is wild. It is a party. Like, I'll be
honest, I thought it was big last year,
but this morning I was blown away by the
size of the group rides, the shakeout
rides, heading out, and then the expo. I
just finished walking and it is bigger
than I've ever seen. It's It's a party,
man. Man, it is a crazy party going on.
Lots of friendly people, lots of people.
You went on one of the shakeout rides.
What was that experience like this
morning? It was awesome. I mean, there
was probably about maybe 4 or 500 of us
that were out on the shakeout ride and
everybody was just having a good time. I
got to talk to a guy from Columbia that
was here for the race and so it was
really cool to get to chat with him for
a little bit. Not Columbia, Missouri.
Yes, correct. Not country. Missouri.
Yes. And so, uh, we got to got to chat
for a little bit and got to kind of
share a little bit of course knowledge,
local knowledge with some folks that
were a little bit worried about road
conditions for tomorrow. But, uh, I'll
be honest, I I think we're going to have
a beautiful day. Yeah. You know, we're
about 20 minutes from the XL start.
We're going to walk down there. We're
going to film and show it to you here in
this quick vlog. Then we're going to
talk about predictions for tomorrow
after that. So, we'll wrap up and we're
headed up to see the XL off.
[Applause]
[Music]
Yeah.
Yeah. Woo.
Okay, Neil, we just watched the XL
takeoff. What was that like for you?
Dude, it's always cool to get to see I
mean that helicopter flying overhead and
all these folks getting ready to go out
and do 350 mi. There's always a little
bit of sadness, you know, inside because
of what happened in 2023. But, uh,
someday, someday, someday, I think I'll
be on that start line again for the XL.
You know, we've both been around this
event for a long time. I think the first
one I covered was in 2011. How crazy is
it to see this on a Friday? Well, I
mean, I was talking to you. I mean, you
know, when the first time I did this was
the 100 back in 2014, and the shakeout
ride again that I went on this morning
had more riders than the hundred did
that year. And just to see this many
folks taking off on a Friday for 355
355ish miles. Uh, absolutely wild. So,
it's it's definitely awesome to see. Uh,
the atmosphere again downtown is great.
And, uh, I love that Emporia has this. I
love it. You know, we talked a lot about
it. A lot of talk about being the
weather. Lots of rain here in May. We
were worried that the sun wouldn't come
out, that it wouldn't be windy. Guess
what? I'm looking at the flag down the
street. I'm feeling it. It's the wind is
blowing. The sun is out. And I'll tell
you, this morning on Yuri's ride, we
went out towards the mud marathon
section from uh 2023 and 2015, and they
didn't actually do that on the route,
but I decided I was going to just ride
off course a little bit, and it was
completely dry. It was ridable. It was
dry. Um, I was able to get through it
without zero problems. No stopping, no
mud collecting on the tires. U, I'm not
saying every road out there is going to
be dry, but I'm telling you what, I
think we're going to have some awesome
conditions for the racers. Not just

the folks are going to be heading out

well. Yeah, I think that's the

it's going to be fast. I think there's

Um, but overall going to be a great day.
Hey, you're going to see this on Friday

platform minister of gravel. But
tomorrow night, race day night,

Emporia, midnight to 3:00 a.m., if you

You know, ministers aren't busy on

covering it. Neil's going to get some
sleep after that before he uh has to
preach on Sunday morning. I'm going to

videos.title: The Toughest Race Of My Life | Unbound 200
videos.description:
After 6 months of training and preparation, Alex Paton has finally made it to the start line of Unbound: 200 miles of gritty gravel and fierce competition. He’s trained for the worst — Kansas' brutal roads, thick mud, relentless heat, and all-out chaos. Alex is aiming for a Top 20 finish in the pro race… but will he make it? 👀 Race mode is ON. This is Alex vs Unbound.

In collaboration with @RideShimano & @rule28Clothing  🤝 
👉 https://gcn.eu/-Shimano 
👉 https://gcn.eu/Rule28

The Global Cycling Network (GCN) is the largest online cycling channel in the world, bringing together a global community of road cyclists to celebrate everything that’s great about the world of cycling.

Our videos bring fans compelling daily content including expert tutorials, techniques, training, racing, cutting-edge bike tech, unparalleled behind the scenes event coverage, humour,  entertainment, and more.

Presented by ex-pro riders, GCN offers a uniquely qualified insight into the world of cycling, and most importantly it’s fuelled by our passionate and enthusiastic fans – everyone who makes up the GCN community. We also bring the latest and greatest tech to your attention, showcase the best places in the world to ride and get exclusive access to events and races.
